target: "Stop! Stop! Take a slave and let us go. Kill us, and they all die regardless!"
Accept their offer.
Surrender is not an option.

BUG BUG BUG BUG THIS IS A BUG!
	You should never ever see this! Please report this to the Multiverse discord with as many specifics as possible including;
	Sector #
	Sector type
	Beacon type (nebula/clearing, distress, store, unmarked, etc)
	MV Version number and hyperspace version number
"Blegh, you're the ship we traveled all the way from Universe 1 to meet? I thought they said you were a THREAT." Looks like you'll have to show these guys not to underestimate you.
"Looks like you've stumbled into my.... AMBUSH! Nyeh heh heh! Heh. Heh... Die." The Rebel ship moves in to attack.
"Your mistake for coming here, bucko. End of the line!" It's the end of the line for someone, but let's hope it's not you!
The Rebel captain says nothing, but imitates a pair of guns with his fingers and draws a line across his throat. When did the Rebels get so childish?
The Rebel captain breaks into laughter upon seeing your ship. You won't take this insult lightly. Not like you have a choice, since their weapons are already firing!
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
You've reached the end of the first step of your journey. However, it appears you aren't alone. The Rebel fleet must have sent one of their fighters after you!
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
You've arrived at the Long-Range Beacon. When the FTL Drive is charged you can jump to the next Sector.
Continue...
You've successfully defeated the Rebel ship. You now have some time to do something else on the ship.
Do something on-board the ship.
Do nothing.
You've successfully defeated the Elite ship, but you don't have any time to do something else because of the fleet.
You have arrived at a Federation supply depot for Multiverse Travellers. These were established across various realities deemed prominent for protection.
This beacon serves as a temporary outpost for Multiverse-drive equipped vessels, established and maintained by the Federation.
You're not surprised to see this beacon has been outfitted with a Multiverse supply depot. Many such beacons were constructed by prior Multiverse Travellers to help prepare ships such as yours.
Continue...
A brief scan of your ID is all it takes until a Federation Auto-ship is dispatched to transfer over some supplies.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
It appears you've arrived a little too late. Something, whether they be pirate or Rebel, has razed this place and destroyed everything in sight. You grab what little salvage remains and carry on.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.

You scan your ID, but no supplies are dispensed. A Federation officer apologizes, explaining their delivery drones were damaged or destroyed by pirates. To compensate, they send one of their repair drones instead, followed by a small team of crew carrying some additional scrap.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Federation officer who greets you apologizes and explains they're short on supplies. The best they can offer is a small helping of fuel and scrap.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Federation officer who greets you apologizes and explains they're short on supplies. The best they can offer is a small helping of ammunition and scrap.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Federation officer who greets you apologizes and explains they're short on supplies. The best they can offer is a small helping of drone parts and scrap.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Little remains of the supply depot other than a small helping of scrap. From the rubble descends a Rebel vessel, but they don't seem interested in fighting.
Attack the ship!
You prepare for battle.
Continue...
Avoid the ship.
You pull away from the supply depot.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Little remains of the supply depot other than a small helping of scrap. A pirate ship jumps in nearby, disappointed to find the supply depot already destroyed.
Attack the ship!
You prepare for battle.
Continue...
Avoid the ship.
You pull away from the supply depot.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Little remains of the supply depot other than a small helping of scrap. A Mantis hunter approaches menacingly, their weapons humming with power, but not firing yet.
Attack the ship!
You prepare for battle.
Continue...
Avoid the ship.
You pull away from the supply depot.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The ship breaks apart and you quickly salvage what you can.
Continue...
With the crew dead you quickly salvage what you can.
Continue...
To no surprise, an MV Rebel is accosting a nearby civilian store owner.
Rescue the store.
You prepare for combat.
Continue...
Ignore the merchant.
Fortunately the ships remain oblivious to your presence.
You're surprised to find another Multiverse ship at this beacon, bearing markings of a pirate vessel.
Continue...

The pirates hail you. "Ah, a fellow traveller! I'm sure we can both relate over the difficulty of upkeep with these MV drives, yes? Well, we've been running low on fuel and I'm sure you could use an upgrade, maybe we can trade?"
Buy an engine upgrade.
Surprisingly, the pirates do honor their deal, and your engines have gained in efficiency. This will be a welcome boost for the road ahead.
Attack them!

"Wait wait wait, before you do that. Look, do the math, right? It's only a handful of fuel, 3 scrap each, right? What I am offering is an upgrade for basically 9 scrap. Think about it! It's a great offer!"
Take the upgrade.
Surprisingly, the pirates do honor their deal, and your engines have gained in efficiency. This will be a welcome boost for the road ahead.
Nah, we'll just kill you.
"Wow, you must really be bad at math, or desperate for fuel. Your stupidity bodes well for me!"
Continue...
No thanks.
"Your loss."
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
A slaver ship approaches, one of the Tiiikaka clan's distributers. In a bold display of characteristic pirate arrogance, the ship opens comms with you and offers several slaves.
See the slaves they're offering.
We can't let pirates waltz in Federation space. Take these guys down!
These pirates have gotten out of hand. Best you clean this reality up of their kind.
Continue...
Decline.
The pirate scoffs and cuts comms.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.

The slaver gives you a tour of the cramped dungeon that he considers fit for keeping living things. It's deplorable, but with some scrap, you can free one of these slaves to work for you instead. It's probably a better fate.
Buy an Engi slave.
Buy a Mantis slave.
Nevermind.

The slaver gives you a tour of the cramped dungeon that he considers fit for keeping living things. It's deplorable, but with some scrap, you can free one of these slaves to work for you instead. It's probably a better fate.
Buy a Rock slave.
Buy an Orchid slave.
Nevermind.

An abandoned supply cache drifts through space nearby. It must have been lost during an attack. You aren't sure who it belongs to - but you could use it for a trap against the fleet, or try your luck with opening it.
Try to carefully open it.
Blow it open!
As a wise man once said - when you can't be certain, just apply a very large amount of militry grade explosives and pray to the high heavens you don't go up in flames.
Continue...
Set a trap for the fleet.
This'll throw them off for a bit. Let's just hope no civilians or Feds get greedy and try to open it first.
Ignore the cache.
You pull away from the cache and leave.
Do something onboard the ship.
This could be an ambush. It is wiser to move past this cache.

Once you get the cache open, you realize the entire thing is filled with explosives! It's for supplies, of course, but if you had tried to blow it open that would have gone very poorly. You take everything inside.
The cache looks to be filled with batteries and other various reactor parts. You could use these to improve the efficiency of your own reactor!
Looks like the cache is protected by some kind of complicated keypad connected to a bomb. Playing with it is too risky. You leave the cache behind, disappointed.
You open up the cache, only to find a band of malnourished and ravenous pirates trapped inside!
Your missiles detonate... only for the entire cache to explode a split second later! The force is so great it even damages your hull. That cache must have been filled with explosives!
The cache looks to be filled with batteries and other various reactor parts. You could use these to improve the efficiency of your own reactor!

The doors of the cache explode, revealing a band of ravenous pirates locked inside. Now exposed to the vacuum of space, they quickly perish. You shuffle past their lifeless bodies and find an armament inside the cache.
To your surprise, an Orchid ship is waiting for you here. Sure, they're a loyal part of the Federation, but the Florals typically prefer to keep to their own turf. What's this about?
Wait for them to hail.

An Orchid appears on screen, gesturing with their hands in native Orchid sign language, which your translator converts into actual audio. "Hello! You must be professor Orwell. We have reviewed the files you gave us and we are most excited to share our scientific findings with the board. We have left a few annotated questions for your review, and will send them over along with payment shortly!"
Yes, that's me. I'm Orwell. Definitely.
"Wonderful!" The Orchids send over a series of annotated videos of what appears to be human adult films with extremely questionable titles, and some scrap.
I'm not 'Orwell'.
"Oh. I am terribly sorry. Would you happen to know the location of the professor?"
Make up some random directions.
The Orchid stares blanky at you. "I'm afraid I don't understand. Are you, as the humans call it, 'pulling my leg'? It would be appreciated if you did not mess with foreigners." The Orchids hang up.
No idea.
"Understandable. I appreciate your straightforwardness. Good day!" The Orchid ship jumps away, but not before leaving you with a few fuel cells as a customary gift.
Attack pre-emptively.
You're barely out the gate of your mission and you're already murdering random innocents. This really does not speak well to your motives.
Continue...
Ignore the Orchids and fly away.
You simply fly past the ship, and they make no attempt to follow you. Odd, but nothing for you to worry about now.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Scans reveal a large asteroid field nearby. Short-range scanners may discover useful materials while we wait for the FTL to recharge.
Explore the asteroid field.
Too dangerous. We'll just wait for the FTL to charge.
You decide to not risk exploring the asteroid field.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
(Scrap Recovery Arm) Attempt to mine the asteroids.
You carefully extract as much usable material as possible from the nearest asteroids while waiting for the FTL to charge.
(Magnetic Arm) Attempt to mine the asteroids.
Your magnetic arm is not well suited to the task, but it is able to salvage a very small portion of space junk drifting around nearby.
(Mining Equipment) Attempt to mine the asteroids.
You carefully extract as much usable material as possible from the nearest asteroids while waiting for the FTL to charge.
A brief exploration yields nothing of interest.
Scans reveal a number of asteroids with useful compositions. You extract some fuel.
You discover the remains of ship embedded into an asteroid. It still has some functional missiles.
You happen upon an abandoned mining site. A few mining drones were left behind and could be repurposed.
The asteroid field proved more dangerous than expected. Some asteroids managed to get through your ship's defenses.
A pirate ship hiding behind one of the larger asteroids attacks you! You're able to escape from the asteroid field, but you can't lose the pirates.
Continue...
It appears several mercenaries are competing for attention at a small inn, hoping to find work aboard a Multiverse vessel.
Hire a crewmember.
Hire a crewmember.
Don't hire anyone.
You ignore the crew.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.

You come across a mining operation around this beacon. "Hail, captain! We've been dispatched to harvest the ores from these asteroids to be used in development of a new experimental fuel source for Multiverse drives. However, we've run short on ammunition... perhaps you could lend us some?"
Give them the requested 5 missiles.
Give them 15 missiles.
(Explosive Replicator) Use the replicator to synthesize the missiles for them.
(Missile Weapon) Offer to blast through the mine with your Launcher.

"I don't think you quite understand. I understand your... enthusiasm... but it's not exactly 'union friendly' to use military ballistic weapons in mining operations. Perhaps it's best we don't make any trades..."
(Bomb Weapon) Offer to solve their problem by using a controlled explosion from your bomb. [-1}]
"Curious. I did not consider the practicality of using a bomb for such matters. I suppose it should be safe enough. You have my permission."
Continue...
(Lost Sun Commando) Offer to teach them how to construct makeshift explosives.

Your commando, being both an experienced arsonist and knowledgeable in the ways of explosives, explains to the miners how the Lost Suns have been using "recycled" ammunition to save costs. Thoroughly impressed by this knowledge, the colony's leader grants you access to some of their latest spoils.
Decline.
"I understand. Good luck out there. We'll try to make do with what we have."
Check the storage.
Do nothing.

A small terraforming team working on a nearby moon hails you, and a short, stubby Rockman captain appears on the screen. "We require assistance, and you are the first ship we've seen in this system for weeks. We're in the middle of terraforming this barren moon, but our sensors aren't strong enough to break through the atmosphere."
You offer your assistance.

"Thank you! We need to scan this planet for life before we can begin terraforming, but our sensors can't get the necessary power to scan through this atmosphere. We've got a schedule to keep, any chance you can help?"
Attempt to scan the planet.
(Advanced Sensors) Set sensors to maximum and scan.
(Zoltan Crew) Send your crewman to overcharge their systems.
(Long-Ranged Scanners) Scan the planet.
(Shell Scientist) Have your Shell assist them.
You do not have time.
"We understand. Best of luck on your mission, sir!"
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
It seems your sensors are no more powerful than the terraformer's. You apologize and continue on your way.
You find if you modulate the feedback signal of your sensors to just the right frequency, you're able to get through the atmosphere and perform a complete scan!
Continue...

After a complete scan of the planet, you find no life. The team is grateful and ready to get to work. The station scientists have a unique talent for life support units and offer to upgrade your oxygen system as thanks.

A complete scan of the planet reveals no life signs other than a single ship on the surface. The terraformers thank you for your help, and attempt to contact the ship. Just as you're about to jump away, the ship takes off and attacks, it's a pirate!
Continue...
A complete scan of the planet reveals a simple mold as the only life present. The terraformers claim their terraforming plans are only hindered by intelligent life; they can begin their work.
Tell them to stop. Any life is valuable.
"But our livelihood depends on this job! Who cares about some silly mold? We'll pay you to look the other way!"
Accept the bribe and leave.
Offer to pay them to at least delay until the mold can be studied.
They see reason and accept the offer. The station scientists have a unique talent for life support units and offer to upgrade your oxygen system as an apology for their behaviour.
Power your weapons and demand they leave at once.
They shut off communications, but you can tell they have begun an evacuation procedure.
Leave them to their work.
Nearby are some Federation fortifications that have taken heavy damage. A couple workers are busy trying to patch up the damage.
Hail and ask if they need any assistance.

"Any help you could offer would be a life saver. We only just barely managed to chase away those damn rebels, and they'll no doubt be returning with reinforcements soon. We're undermanned and we won't be able to get these repairs done in time."
Offer to wait behind longer and fight off the Rebels.
You wait behind until you spot a small squadron of Rebel ships approaching. Hurry to combat positions!
Continue...
Lend a crew member to stay and assist them.
Though it's only one man, the Federation officers seem to understand the weight of your decision and pay you greatly for your sacrifice.
Your crew cannot be cloned as they are not dead.
We can't help.
You apologize and end comms.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Ignore them.
The staff will hopefully be able to repair their defenses in time before the fleet arrives.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Rebel ships jump away once again, leaving you and the fortifications behind.
Continue...

"Thank you for your help, but I am afraid this is very unfortunate that they got away. We know you can't wait behind any longer, and I don't think anyone else will arrive in time to assist us. Still, at least it buys us some time. We can't offer too much, but perhaps this fuel will help."
It appears the rest of the Rebel squadron is trying to flee after watching their comrades be destroyed by you. The Federation officers thank you and offer payment.
"You winnings! Most greatest of fighters. As promise, I coming with."
By mistake it appears you have accidentally slain the Free Mantis. There's nothing left but to scrap their hull.
By mistake it appears you have accidentally slain the Free Mantis. There's nothing left but to scrap their hull.
Continue...
(Medical Crew) Revive the Free Mantis.
Once safely returned to the realm of the living, the Free Mantis applauds you. "Excellency of fighter beyond any realm of imaginings! I must coming with and see you in further action."
(Upg. Medbay) Revive the Free Mantis.
Once safely returned to the realm of the living, the Free Mantis applauds you. "Excellency of fighter beyond any realm of imaginings! I must coming with and see you in further action."
(Upg. Clone Bay) Revive the Free Mantis.
Once safely returned to the realm of the living, the Free Mantis applauds you. "Excellency of fighter beyond any realm of imaginings! I must coming with and see you in further action."
(Reconstructive Teleporter) Revive the Free Mantis.
Once safely returned to the realm of the living, the Free Mantis applauds you. "Excellency of fighter beyond any realm of imaginings! I must coming with and see you in further action."
(Healing Bomb) Revive the Free Mantis.
Once safely returned to the realm of the living, the Free Mantis applauds you. "Excellency of fighter beyond any realm of imaginings! I must coming with and see you in further action."

A Free Mantis greets you eagerly, their broken dialogue challenging the translator to keep up. "Oh Federation captain, I asking of you if you are worthy of my support! Yes, I having faith, but I must seeing proof. Fighting me, winning and I joining of crew. Just knowing be careful, I not taking mercies on you!"
Accept his challenge.
"Then battle shall commencing!" You'll have to rough their hull up a bit to win. If you kill them all, there won't be anyone left to join your crew.
Continue...
Decline.
"You are most of borings." The Free Mantis don't seem all that offended despite their message, and wave goodbye as you pass.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The pirates hail you. "Ok, you've made your point Mr. Feddy Man. These are your supplies, yes yes, but we need to be able to feed ourselves too! How about we make a compromise?"
Agree to their compromise and split the supplies.
You collect the supplies and leave the pirates alone.
Refuse.

It appears this beacon is home to a Federation outpost... or at least it was, until a band of pirates came by and ravaged the place! There might be some supplies left behind if you can clear out the attackers.
Attack the pirates!
Those supplies belong to the Federation, not these damn pirates! You prepare for combat.
Continue...
Ignore them, it's not worth the effort.
The pirates can help themselves to those supplies, they'll need everything they can get until the Rebel fleet catches up and destroys them.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
You've defeated the pirates. Not eager to mess with you further, the rest of their clan scatter.
Salvage the remaining supplies.
You skirt around the edge of the depot, looking for any remaining loot. Though the pirates took all of the weapons and armor, quite a few resources remain.
Several Civilian vessels have landed on a nearby moon around a Federation Multiverse warp-bay. You can see crowds gathering but you aren't sure why.
Investigate.

The Civilians appear to be protesting, gathering in large groups and holding up signs. It appears the crowd is against the use of Multiverse travel, thinking it endangers their ways of life. The Federation soldiers hold their ground and try to fend off the civilians, but it appears the situation is getting heated.
Attack one of the civilian vessels.
You open fire on one of the civilian vessels nearby.
Continue...
Send in a team of crew to assist.
Fly away.
You pull away from the moon before you're spotted.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Ignore the crowds.
You have no interest in whatever is happening on the moon.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The rest of the civilians, having seen your brutal attack, flee in fear. This won't help improve the public view of the Multiverse Travellers, but at least the Federation soldiers were saved.

It appears your attack drove many of the Civilians to violence, and full-scale fighting has broken out in the streets. One civilian ship with a particularly nasty looking missile launcher tears through your hull, and you pull away quickly.

The civilians are forced to flee as the Federation soldiers take this opportunity to retake the block and drive back the protesters. The whole situation goes over with few casualties, save for the civilians you just murdered. The Federation staff is thankful for your assistance, though disapproving of your methods, and offer some supplies.

You land the vessel right in the middle of the conflict, careful not to squish anyone. Your crew exit and talk over the situation with the protesters. They manage to convince them not to resort to violence, the crowds slowly dwindle away.

The situation is too chaotic for you to land the ship nearby, so you pilot a short distance away from the main scene of conflict and drop off your crew. They're dragged into what has now descended into full on gun fire, and one of your crew is tagged straight in the chest with blaster fire! You give orders for the rest of the team to head back to the ship immediately.
Fortunately your Clone Bay is able to revive your crew member, but you aren't willing to risk sending them back in.

By the time your crew arrive the situation has already escalated. They manage to rescue one of the Federation staff, a medical unit who was caught in the cross-fire, and bring them back to the ship. Unfortunately, it seems a few of the protesters noticed and have followed you back to the ship!

A blip on the communicator shows an incoming transmission from a Zoltan ship out of your field of view. When you pick up, you're greeted by the unwelcome sounds of a raving madman screeching about 'cowering beneath the prophet eye.' He demands a prayer and offering, or else suffer his wrath.
Refuse.
Pay him. [-20~]
(Monk Crew) Retaliate with even greater spiritual nonsense.

Both Zoltans launch into a long debate that gets so heated it eventually reaches a point not even your translator can comprehend the words they are saying. That's mostly because they aren't words, just primal screeching. Your monk returns and reports that the second Zoltan died during the argument, and implores you to not ask questions. You scrap his ship.
(Medical Crew) Evaluate his condition.

Your crew determines he has some kind of mind erosion, not uncommon for elderly Zoltan as their hard-light forms start to deteriorate. They manage to talk some sense into the Zoltan, and convince him to stand down while they take a look at his situation. They manage to patch him up, and in return he joins your crew.
(Medical Drone) Evaluate his condition.

Your drone determines he has some kind of mind erosion, not uncommon for elderly Zoltan as their hard-light forms start to deteriorate. They manage to talk some sense into the Zoltan, and convince him to stand down while they take a look at his situation. They manage to patch him up, and in return he joins your crew.
Ignore them.
You've barely started your journey, and you don't intend to dedicate time to listen to the ramblings of a grumpy Zoltan elder.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Zoltan shouts an insult or two at you, but eventually his ramblings go quiet and the ship jumps away. As far as you can tell, nothing bad has happened from this, and likely never will.

"Then let the curse befall you!" The Zoltan ship jumps away, and are immediately followed by a Rebel ship jumping in! Were the Zoltan working with the Rebels, or is this a pure coincidence? Hard to say, but one thing's for certain. It's time to fight!
Continue...

"Then let the curse befall you!" The Zoltan ship jumps away, and are immediately followed by a Rebel ship jumping in! Were the Zoltan working with the Rebels, or is this a pure coincidence? Hard to say, but one thing's for certain. It's time to fight!
Continue...
The Zoltan yells some more obscene nonsense, scoops up the scrap, and jumps away.
The Zoltan scoops up the scrap, and says something prophetic about your good fortune. He jumps away shortly after.
Go looking for the Rebel ship.
No time to search, you prepare to jump away.
You decide not to go hunting for Rebels.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
(Improved Sensors) Perform a scan of the area.
You quickly find the Rebel ship's location and move to intercept.
Continue...
(Advanced Sensors) Pinpoint the Rebel's location.
You find the Rebel ship hiding on a nearby asteroid. You are able to get a shot off and permanently disable their engines before they notice you.
Continue...
You spend some time looking around but your scanners cannot pick up any trace of the Rebel ship. You prepare to move on.
After a short search you find the Rebel ship. Let's hope he's as easy to defeat in combat as he was to find.
Continue...
You are able to quickly track down the Rebel. Let's hope he's as easy to defeat in combat as he was to find.
Continue...
After far too much time spent searching, you are finally able to track him down. You go into the fight pondering just how much of a head start you've lost on the Rebel Fleet...
Continue...
Your sensors have picked up a refugee ship drifting through the system, no doubt one of many fleeing the Rebel advance. It doesn't appear to have detected you... or else it is trying to avoid notice.
Hail them.
Ignore the refugees.
You decide to ignore the refugees.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
As you hail the freighter, it advances, weapons bristling from its hull! It's a pirate ambush!
Continue...
As you hail the refugee ship, a Rebel ship jumps into the system... they must have been hunting these refugees, but since you're a Federation ship you've taken higher priority on their list.
Continue...
As you hail the refugee ship, a Rebel ship jumps into the system... they must have been hunting these refugees, but since you're a Federation ship you've taken higher priority on their list.
Continue...
As you hail the refugee ship, a Mantis ship jumps into the system... they must have been hunting these civilians but now that they've found you they've changed targets!
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
Continue...
You arrive at the beacon and immediately detect a pirate ship. It seems this distress beacon was a trap!
"Haha! I knew someone would fall into our dastardly trap!" It appears this distress beacon was nothing but a decoy for a pirate ambush.
Your cockpit lights up with warning signals. You are being targeted by a nearby ship. The distress call was a lure to attract unwitting ships into weapons range. You prepare for a fight.
As soon as you arrive at the distress signal, shots are fired toward your ship. A trap!

You arrive at the distress beacon near a small asteroid belt and find a ship with pirate markings partially crushed between two large rocks. It must have been illegally mining the belt without proper equipment.
Try to dislodge the ship by shooting at the rocks.
Destroy and loot the ship. They're just pirates.
(Beam Weapon) Carefully cut the ship out.
You use your beam to make a few precision cuts in the asteroid. The ship gives a quick burst of thrust and the rock crumbles away. They thank you and offer some of the resources they have collected.
(Damaging Pinpoint Weapon) Attempt to meticulously cut out the pirate ship.

With what is possibly the dumbest decision you have ever made, you take the increduously long time to chip away at the asteroid with your Pinpoint. You're certain the fleet has caught up by now and you've barely made any impact, giving you no choice but to abandon the pirate ship.
(Beam Drone) Have your drone cut the ship out.
You program the drone to work carefully around the trapped ship. In a short time it allows the ship to easily slip out of its cage. They thank you and offer some of the resources they have collected.

You take a few careful shots but you expose a mineral patch in the rock that reacts violently with your weapon. A shockwave forces you back as debris pelts against your hull. When you regain control you find there is not much left of the ship.
You fire a few volleys into the rock and it starts to shudder and break apart. Without shields the pirate ship takes a beating but eventually pulls free. They thank you for your assistance.
You decide the pirate is not worth saving and fire a few volleys into their hull causing the ship to depressurize and break apart. You move in to loot the remains.

You decide the pirate is not worth saving and fire a few volleys into their hull. Before you can scrap the remains another pirate ship flashes on your radar. Perhaps they saw your deed, or perhaps they want to claim the spoils for themselves, but for whatever reason, they're charging weapons!
Continue...

You arrive at a lonely planet orbiting a dying star. A quick scan of the surface reveals a ship crash landed on the far side of the planet. It's in shambles, but there is a chance someone may have survived.
Pull closer.
Ignore the planet.
Even if someone did survive, there's not much you could do to help them.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
You've defeated the Rebel ship. You scrap its remains.
Continue...
The Rebel carrier was in worse condition than you thought. The rest of its fleet is offline and they are defenseless against you. They give you some supplies as a surrender.
You've defeated the Rebel ship. You scrap its remains.
Continue...
The Rebel carrier was in worse condition than you thought. The rest of its fleet is offline and they are defenseless against you. They give you some supplies as a surrender.
The ship here is no ordinary vessel. It's a massive Rebel carrier! It must have detected you, because its few remaining systems come online and it dispenses a ship to face you.
Continue...
The ship that crashed appears to be a Federation Dreadnaught! There may still be crew alive, but the ship seems to be in a critical state.
Try to rescue the crew.
It's too late, we should go.
The ship appears to have once been a Federation carrier, but it's beyond repair. A good section of the hull has collapsed and it's very doubtful anyone survived.
Scrap the ship.
We aren't pirates, it would be disrespectful to scrap the ship.
Your crew returns with a single survivor. It appears the rest of the Federation crew were either killed in the crash or the following inferno.
You watch in horror as the carrier collapses, no doubt burying your crew inside.
Luckily your crew is already being cloned and is revived a short time later.
You are uninterrupted as you salvage the carrier.
It appears one of the Federation Auto-ships onboard is still functional! It detects your attempts at salvaging as hostile and attacks.
Continue...

Once you arrive at this populated region, you immediately pick up a distress signal. A small shuttle is asking anyone who'll listen for help protecting their family from a Rebel ship. Unsurprisingly, no one has yet responded to their request.
See if you can assist them.

It seems that a small space dock has done something to anger the Rebels. The store there is run by his family and he pleads that you rescue them. He uploads the coordinates of the station to your navigation system.
Ignore their pleas.
You block the channel and prepare to jump as soon as possible.

Once you arrive at the beacon you detect a Rebel scout assaulting a compound on a nearby desolate moon.

After a short time you receive a message, "Hello. I hope it's not a bother, but I'm looking for an escort to a nearby system. This region is quite dangerous and our ship is not well-armed."
There is a single ship at this beacon. They hail you, "We could really use some help. Our FTL navigation system is shot. Can you help us get to a nearby station where they can patch us up?"
"Hello," your communicator opens a hail from a nearby ship. "Our weapon systems are malfunctioning and we're too afraid of pirates to travel home unassisted. Can you escort us?"
You escort the ship to the requested beacon. Much to your dismay you are ambushed by a Rebel ship. You walked right into their trap!
Continue...

The ship you were escorting thanks you, "I don't think we could have made it without your help. Let my friends patch up some of your hull and show you their wares."
You arrive and the ship you were escorting jumps in behind you. "Thanks for the help. We work at a nearby fusion power plant, we could try to improve your reactor's output as a form of compensation."
